Paragraph: Recognizes named entities (person and company names, etc.) in text. Principally, this annotator uses one or more machine learning sequence models to label entities, but it may also call specialist rule-based components, such as for labeling and interpreting times and dates. Numerical entities that require normalization, e.g., dates, have their normalized value stored in NormalizedNamedEntityTagAnnotation. For more extensive support for rule-based NER, you may also want to look at the RegexNER annotator. The set of entities recognized is language-dependent, and the recognized set of entities is frequently more limited for other languages than what is described below for English. As the name “NERClassifierCombiner” implies, commonly this annotator will run several named entity recognizers and then combine their results but it can run just a single annotator or only rule-based quantity NER.
Ground truth tasks:
use specialist rule
learn sequence models to label entities
call specialist rule-based components
describe for english
run several named entity recognizers
run single annotator
Program tasks:
use machine
learn sequence models to label entities
call specialist rule-based components
store  in normalizednamedentitytagannotation
describe  for english
run several named entity recognizers
combine results
run single annotator

Paragraph: For English, by default, this annotator recognizes named (PERSON, LOCATION, ORGANIZATION, MISC), numerical (MONEY, NUMBER, ORDINAL, PERCENT), and temporal (DATE, TIME, DURATION, SET) entities (12 classes). Adding the regexner annotator and using the supplied RegexNER pattern files adds support for the fine-grained and additional entity classes EMAIL, URL, CITY, STATE_OR_PROVINCE, COUNTRY, NATIONALITY, RELIGION, (job) TITLE, IDEOLOGY, CRIMINAL_CHARGE, CAUSE_OF_DEATH, (Twitter, etc.) HANDLE (12 classes) for a total of 24 classes. Named entities are recognized using a combination of three CRF sequence taggers trained on various corpora, including CoNLL, ACE, MUC, and ERE corpora. Numerical entities are recognized using a rule-based system.
Ground truth tasks:
add regexner annotator
use regexner pattern files
add support for additional entity classes
use combination of crf sequence taggers
use rule-based system
recognize person
recognize location
recognize organization
recognize misc
recognize money
recognize number
recognize ordinal
recognize percent
recognize date
recognize time
recognize duration
recognize set
Program tasks:
add regexner annotator
use regexner pattern files
add support for additional entity classes
use combination of crf sequence taggers
use rule-based system

Paragraph: During this phase a series of trained CRF’s will be run on each sentence. These CRF’s are trained on large tagged data sets. They evaluate the entire sequence and pick the optimal tag sequence.
Ground truth tasks: run series of trained crf’s
Program tasks:
run series of trained crf 's
run series during phase
run series on sentence

Paragraph: These are the default models that are run:
Ground truth tasks: run default models
Program tasks: run default models

Paragraph: There are two options for how the models are combined. These are selected with the ner.combinationMode property.
Ground truth tasks:
combine models
select with ner.combinationmode property
Program tasks:
combine models
select  with ner.combinationmode property

Paragraph: So for example, if the ner.combinationMode is set to NORMAL, only the 3-class model’s ORGANIZATION tags will be applied. If it is set to HIGH_RECALL, the 7-class and 4-class models’ ORGANIZATION tags will also be applied.
Ground truth tasks:
set ner.combinationmode to normal
set to high_recall
Program tasks:
set ner.combinationmode to normal
apply organization tags
set  to high_recall

Paragraph: If you do not want to run any statistical models, set ner.model to the empty string.
Ground truth tasks:
run statistical models
set ner.model to empty string
Program tasks:
run statistical models
set ner.model to empty string

Paragraph: This phase runs by default, but can be deactivated by setting ner.applyNumericClassifiers to false.

set ner.applynumericclassifiers to false
deactivate phase
Program tasks:

run  by default
deactivate phase

Paragraph: This produces tags such as NUMBER, ORDINAL, MONEY, DATE, and TIME

Paragraph: SUTime (described in more detail below) is also used by default. You can deactivate this by setting ner.useSUTime to false.
Ground truth tasks:
set ner.usesutime to false
use sutime
Program tasks:
use sutime
deactivate  by setting
set ner.usesutime to false

Paragraph: At this point, a series of rules used for the KBP 2017 competition will be run to create more fine-grained NER tags. These rules are applied using a TokensRegexNERAnnotator sub-annotator. That is the main NERCombinerAnnotator builds a TokensRegexNERAnnotator as a sub-annotator and runs it on all sentences as part of it’s entire tagging process. The purpose of these rules is give tokens more specific tags. So for instance California would be tagged as a STATE_OR_PROVINCE rather than just a LOCATION.
Ground truth tasks:
create more fine-grained ner tags
run series of rules
use tokensregexnerannotator sub-annotator
run main nercombinerannotator on sentences
Program tasks:
create more fine-grained ner tags
use  for kbp competition
run series at point
run series of rules
use tokensregexnerannotator sub-annotator
apply rules
run main nercombinerannotator on sentences

Paragraph: The TokensRegexNERAnnotator runs TokensRegex rules. You can review all of the settings for a TokensRegexNERAnnotator here.
Ground truth tasks: run tokensregex rules
Program tasks: run tokensregex rules

Paragraph: If you do not want to run the fine-grained rules, set ner.applyFineGrained to false.
Ground truth tasks:
run fine-grained rules
set ner.applyfinegrained to false
Program tasks:
run fine-grained rules
set ner.applyfinegrained to false

Paragraph: The first column is the tokens pattern, the second column is the NER tag to apply, the third is the types of NER tags that can be overwritten, and the fourth is a priority used for tie-breaking if two rules match a sequence.
Ground truth tasks:
match sequence
use for tie-breaking
Program tasks:
match sequence

Paragraph: Here is a breakdown of how to customize the fine-grained NER. The overall ner annotator creates a sub-annotator called ner.fine.regexner which is an instance of a TokensRegexNERAnnotator.

Paragraph: If you want to run a series of TokensRegex rules before entity building, you can also specify a set of TokensRegex rules. A TokensRegexAnnotator sub-annotator will be called. It has the name ner.additional.tokensregex.

Paragraph: After all of the previous steps have been run, entity detection will be run to combine the tagged tokens into entities. The entity mention detection will be based off of the tagging scheme. This is accomplished with an EntityMentionsAnnotator sub-annotator.
Ground truth tasks:
combine tagged tokens into entities
run entity detection
Program tasks:
combine tagged tokens into entities
run entity detection

Paragraph: If a basic IO tagging scheme (example: PERSON, ORGANIZATION, LOCATION) is used, all contiguous sequences of tokens with the same tag will be marked as an entity.
Ground truth tasks:
mark contiguous sequences as entity
mark contiguous sequences of tokens
Program tasks:
mark contiguous sequences as entity
mark contiguous sequences of tokens
use basic io tagging scheme

Paragraph: If a more advanced tagging scheme (such as BIO with tags like B-PERSON and I-PERSON) is used, sequences with the same tag split by a B-tag will be turned into multiple entities.
Ground truth tasks: use advanced tagging scheme
Program tasks: use advanced tagging scheme

Paragraph: All of our models and rule files use a basic tagging scheme, but you could create your own models and rules that use BIO.
Ground truth tasks:
create own models
use bio

Paragraph: Stanford CoreNLP includes SUTime, Stanford’s temporal expression recognizer. SUTime is transparently called from the “ner” annotator, so no configuration is necessary. Furthermore, the “cleanxml” annotator can extract the reference date for a given XML document, so relative dates, e.g., “yesterday”, are transparently normalized with no configuration necessary.
Ground truth tasks: incluce sutime
Program tasks:
include sutime
call  from ner annotator

Paragraph: SUTime supports the same annotations as before, i.e., NamedEntityTagAnnotation is set with the label of the numeric entity (DATE, TIME, DURATION, MONEY, PERCENT, or NUMBER) and NormalizedNamedEntityTagAnnotation is set to the value of the normalized temporal expression.
Ground truth tasks:
set namedentitytagannotation with label
set normalizednamedentitytagannotation to value
Program tasks:
support same annotations
set namedentitytagannotation with label
set normalizednamedentitytagannotation to value

Paragraph: Also, SUTime sets the TimexAnnotation key to an edu.stanford.nlp.time.Timex object, which contains the complete list of TIMEX3 fields for the corresponding expressions, such as “val”, “alt_val”, “type”, “tid”. This might be useful to developers interested in recovering complete TIMEX3 expressions.
Ground truth tasks: set timexannotation key to edu.stanford.nlp.time.timex object
Program tasks: set timexannotation key to edu.stanford.nlp.time.timex object

Paragraph: Reference dates are by default extracted from the “datetime” and “date” tags in an xml document. To set a different set of tags to use, use the clean.datetags property. When using the API, reference dates can be added to an Annotation via edu.stanford.nlp.ling.CoreAnnotations.DocDateAnnotation, although note that when processing an xml document, the cleanxml annotator will overwrite the DocDateAnnotation if “datetime” or “date” are specified in the document.
Ground truth tasks:
set different set of tags
use clean.datetags property
process xml document
add reference dates to annotation
Program tasks:
set different set of tags
use clean.datetags property
use api
process xml document
overwrite docdateannotation
add reference dates to annotation
specify datetime in document
specify date in document

Paragraph: The DocDateAnnotator provides a variety of options for setting the document date. The ner annotator will run this annotator as a sub-annotator. These can be specified by setting properties for the ner.docdate sub-annotator.

Program tasks:

set properties for ner.docdate sub-annotator

Paragraph: The following example shows how to access label confidences for tokens and entities. Each token stores the probability of its NER label given by the CRF that was used to assign the label in the CoreAnnotations.NamedEntityTagProbsAnnotation.class. Each entity mention contains the probability of the token with the lowest label probability in its span. For example if Los Angeles had the following probabilities:
Ground truth tasks:
access label confidences for tokens
access label confidences for entities
store probability of ner label
use crf
Program tasks:
access label confidences for tokens
access label confidences for entities
store probability of ner label
assign label in coreannotations.namedentitytagprobsannotation.class
use crf
